title: 106_hr515
content: The Act may be cited as the "Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act." The Congress finds that in the 10 years from 1987 through 1996, nearly 2,200 children in the United States aged 14 or younger died from unintentional shootings. The United States leads in rates of children lost to unintentional firearms-related death compared to other industrialized countries. Additionally, the number of nonfatal unintentional firearm injuries treated in U.S. hospital emergency rooms annually is significantly higher. In the United States, children as young as 3 years old are capable of firing most commercially available handguns. Currently, firearms are not subject to minimum safety standards in the country. A 1997 poll found that 74% of Americans support safety regulation of the firearms industry, as firearms and safety locks involved in interstate commerce are often inadequate to prevent accidental discharge or children accessing them. SEC. 3. REGULATION OF HANDGUN DISCHARGE PROTECTION PRODUCTS. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to regulate handgun discharge protection products to reduce the risk of injury to children. The regulations must establish a minimum safety standard for these products, ensuring they are of high quality and cannot be easily removed from a handgun without proper authorization. The Secretary of the Treasury must regulate handgun safety products to prevent injury to children. The standard must ensure these products are secure and can only be accessed with authorized methods. Test protocols for poison prevention packaging may be considered. The standard must be issued within 12 months and take effect 6 months after issuance. SEC. 4. ORDERS; INSPECTIONS. The Secretary has the authority to issue orders prohibiting the manufacture, sale, transfer, or delivery of handgun discharge protection products that violate the Act. They can also require manufacturers and dealers to provide notice of associated risks and how to mitigate them. The Secretary has the authority to issue orders prohibiting the manufacture, sale, transfer, or delivery of handgun discharge protection products that violate the Act. Manufacturers and dealers must bring products into compliance, repair, replace, refund, recall, or submit a plan for implementation. The Secretary can inspect manufacturing and storage areas for compliance with the Act. The Secretary has the authority to inspect areas where handgun discharge protection products are manufactured, stored, or held for distribution in commerce. They can also enter and inspect conveyances used for commercial transportation of such products. SEC. 5 of the document outlines unlawful acts related to handgun discharge protection products, requiring licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers to comply with specific standards. There is an exception for sales to government agencies. SEC. 6 addresses the requirement for warning labels on handguns. SEC. 6 requires licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers to include warning labels on handgun packaging to prevent child access and potential injuries or death. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. This section outlines the reporting requirements related to the warning labels on handgun packaging mandated in the previous section. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers must report any information indicating a child's injury or death from a handgun sold after the Act's effective date. The Secretary may assess civil penalties up to $10,000 for violations of the Act, revoke federal firearms licenses for violations, and individuals can bring a private cause of action for damages in court. Private enforcement of the Act allows any interested person to bring an action in a US district court to enforce the Act or restrain violations. The court may award attorney's fees to a prevailing plaintiff. Compliance with the Act does not relieve liability under common law or State law, and the Secretary's failure to take action is not admissible in litigation. Under this Act, evidence of the Secretary's failure to take action is not admissible in litigation. Criminal penalties include fines and imprisonment for knowingly violating provisions of the Act regarding handgun discharge protection products. SEC. 9. NO EFFECT ON STATE LAW. This Act does not affect State laws unless they conflict with it, and State laws providing greater protection to children regarding handguns are not considered inconsistent with this Act. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. This section defines terms such as "handgun discharge protection product," "children," "licensed importer," "licensed manufacturer," "licensed dealer," "Secretary," and "handgun" as per section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code.
